content.description: Start under the roof low with a sidepull and work your way out to a jug rail. All routes share the same start. Go up to some bullet hard pockets and traverse right on more amazing pockets while trying to keep your feet. The problem exits the cave to the right on jugs. Be careful with the top out and make sure you know what you are grabbing before committing to the top out. Climbed out over some bones of a lion kill.
content.location: starts in the middle right of the cave on low sidepulls below the slopey jug rail.  The line works its way out to the far right.

content.description: This is a secluded section with a world class roof about a 20 minute hike in on the hermit trail. Climbing is similar to priest draw pockets. Follow the Hermit trail down about 15 minutes until you follow a shallow draw with some rocks on either side. You will pass a sort of dam feature. Drop off trail past the dam and walk into the wash for another minute or two. The wash pours off over a limestone cave. This is your cave. Find a way to downclimb and enjoy bomber pockets on a horizontal roof. There are about 5 or 6 good lines here and definitely room for variation. This wall would get 5 stars just about anywhere. Please respect this area. It is one of the more secluded trails on the South Rim and has a wilderness feel. You might find fresh Mt lion kill sites in the cave from time to time. This particular cave is free of archaeological resources, but caves nearby are off limits for development. Tread lightly and enjoy some world class bouldering. Bring at least one pad and a spotter. Top outs are a bit dirty and tall.
